Algebra

Essential formulas and concepts in algebra

Quadratic Formula

\(x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\)

Variables:

Description/Usage:

Gives the solutions for a quadratic equation of any form. It is typically illustrated by the parabola of \(y = ax^2+bx+c\) intersecting the \(x\)-axis at \(x\) values given by this formula (the roots).

Binomial Theorem

\((a + b)^n = \sum_{k=0}^{n}\binom{n}{k} a^{n-k} b^k\)

Variables:

Description/Usage:

Expands a binomial raised to an integer power into a sum of terms. Often visualized using Pascalâ€™s Triangle for binomial coefficients.

Common Factoring Identity (Difference of Squares)

\(a^2 - b^2 = (a+b)(a-b)\)

Variables:

  • \(a and b are any expressions or numbers.\)

Description/Usage:

Fundamental algebraic identity used to factor the difference between two squares. Itâ€™s often demonstrated graphically by the difference in areas of squares of side \(a\) and side \(b\).

Mathematical concept visualization

Combination Formula

\(\displaystyle \binom{n}{k} = \frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!}\)

Variables:

Description/Usage:

Computes the number of ways to choose \(k\) items from \(n\) without order. This formula is central in combinatorics and appears in binomial expansions and probability calculations.
